--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> --- Tyler Streeter <tylerstreeter@...> wrote:
> > 
> > > * joint angles
> > > * forces on body parts
> > >
> > > Those are the things that an actual human being
> is
> > > able to sense directly.
> > 
> > I've been thinking about this idea quite a bit-
> > things
> > we can sense directly and "senses" we deduce from
> > our
> > more direct senses.  Can we directly sense joint
> > angles?  I'm guessing not.  I think we probably
> > deduce
> > that from our more direct "force" senses (i.e.
> sense
> > of touch).  ...Not that that matters for this
> > project.
> 
> It is well established that humans have a
> "kinesthetic
> sense" which let's them "feel" the position of their
> various body parts.  You can experience it.  Just
> close your eyes and move your arms into different
> positions, or better yet, relax them and have
> someone
> else put them in different positions.  Can you feel
> where your arms are?  (You should be able to.)

I'm still not totally convinced that the kinesthetic
sense is something we sense "directly."  It's really
hard to separate what's being sensed directly as
signals from our nerves and what our minds compose
from these more primitive input signals.  Having a
continuous memory of where our limbs are positioned
probably helps.

When I or someone else puts my arms in different
positions, I really can't tell how I know where my
arms are  (if that makes sense).  Is that information
just being constructed in my mind from a bunch of
signals coming from my nerves?  I guess we probably
have hierarchies of neural modules that automatically
abstract all kinds of functions, so it's hard to tell
what's really going on.

I guess I'm thinking aloud too much, and I'm certainly
not an expert on this.  What does anyone else think?

Tyler
